ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Basic statistics and coding in R.

I learned about the foundations of statistics and understood how to analyze data on the basic level. I've already used these skills for my work as a research assistant in the PoliSci sphere. The class is more advanced than other introductory courses, covering more material and more in-depth than other courses.

knowledge: intro to probability theory, hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, power, causality and correlation
skills: how to use R, run simulations etc.
R programming language, data analysis, and the basics of statistics.
I learned intro-level statistical applications, such as sampling from populations, regression, and t-testing.
Statistics and R
Throughout this course I became acquainted with R as well as a lot of basic statistical concepts that have informed my daily life!
Introductory statistics (concepts/theory and practice, including R) and a sense of statistical practice

I learned a lot about probability and statistical inference. I have a solid working knowledge of R language now, and I gained a lot of general insight into how statisticians make predictions and inference about data.
How to effectively synthesize information from textbooks

I learned about various topics in statistics, as well as how to learn about other topics on my own. The variety of topics was nice, and I feel like I can both understand and produce statistical information more effectively.
Gained a detailed introduction in to Stats with probability, regression, sampling, etc. In addition, this class lays a strong foundation for R.
I have gained a foundation in statistics as well as experience and familiarity working with R.
In this course we gained a good introduction to basic statistics, as well as implementations of common statistical methods in the R language.
I learned how to code in R as well as different probability models and theories.
I learned an intro to probabilty and frequentist statistics. I learned how to apply these concepts to actual data sets. I learned to use R to do statistical tests, organize data, and create graphs.
Basic statistical methods, basics of bayesian statistics, normal distributions, bootstrapping, etc.
I learned a ton of R
In depth introduction to statistics and basic knowledge of R

How to use R
What linear regression, correlation, etc are and how to calculate them

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: Interesting and useful material, and the programming often helped understand exactly what the formulas are doing. Weaknesses: Lectures were sometimes confusing, and there was nothing on the psets that you couldn't just google.

The strengths of this course are the depth of material we learn and a good balance between theoretical and practical knowledge. I learned a lot of computing alongside traditional statistical theory, which allows me to not only write code but understand how the functions work on the basic level.

Strengths: learned a lot of material, problem sets were challenging, but helped to solidify class material
Weaknesses: sometimes lectures went too fast to follow

Strengths: office hours, available resources
Weaknesses: often it felt like we weren't covering important topics in great detail. Prof. Chang would spend a lot of time explaining stats processes and then gloss over the R functions needed for them, which would have been helpful for the psets.

One strength is that I learned a lot from the class and it helped me build a strong foundation for data science classes I will take in the future. One weakness is that it was a bit disorganized and there was not a clear syllabus that we could refer to for grading distributions, late homework policy, etc.
This class was easy to approach at first, but quickly ramped up. I feel as though it was not adequately paced.

I felt as if there could have been a clearer connection between the concepts discussed in class and what was asked of us in the homework. Although I felt as if the exams were mostly fair, at times the psets were much more complicated than we were reasonably prepared for. I also wouldn't describe this course as exactly introductory, having never taken statistics before, I definitely struggled with the pace and what was asked of us in the psets.

Everything was well-explained and paced, and the professor was clearly very knowledgeable. But the pacing of assessments didn't always make sense, especially having a computational exam one week before the timed final.

I have only strengths for this course. There was (in my opinion) a perfect balance between teaching with slides and with R script, and the two modes of learning complemented each other very well. Concepts were introduced and followed up with specific examples, so this course avoided some of the more mundane aspects of an intro statistics class that I've heard many people talk about before. Most importantly, everything we did had a purpose. Not once did I wonder why we were learning what we were learning, and I was always interested by the practical applications of the subject matter.
Weaknesses: Poor communication with Professor Chang and TAs, ED discussion took an average of 5 days to be responded to, and PSet grades took forever to come out.
The PSets and lectures were good. I only wish there had been office hours on the day that PSets were due, after 10:30 AM.

The psets were usually quite enjoyable to work on. In particular, I always enjoyed the more R-focused questions (as opposed to the calculations-by-hand type questions from the textbook). The content covered by the course felt mostly comprehensive, but I would be interested in knowing what other foundational aspects of statistics were not covered.
A strength was the positivity of the teacher. A weakness was that we didn't get at ton of practice with some concepts covered in class. Office hours were not particularly helpful either.
I liked the class. It was good. It took a while for us to get some of our grades back.
Great class. No glaring weaknesses

Weakness: Prof Chang. I have never had a professor that cared so little about his students. Honestly the amount of support in this class was so bad that at some point you start feeling incredibly frustrated. Professor Chang is also a TERRIBLE writer, like he would write problems that literally you cannot understand because it is not proper English, and when you email him he will tell you to post it on Ed and he will then respond AFTER THE PSET IS DUE(like wtf) 

Strengths: When you can read the problems and make sense out of them, the psets could be fun.

This course could have included more applications of statistics which would have made it more interesting. Also I would have appreciated some structured group work or in-class discussions - basically an opportunity to apply and think more generally about all the specifics we were learning. Strength is that it covered a really wide variety of statistics topics

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course was well-adapted for the COVID-19 pandemic.
Recorded lectures were a great advantage because they allowed students to re-watch parts of lecture that they didn't understand. Prof. Chang was happy to take questions during lecture.
I thought it was well designed for the circumstance.
I feel as if it would have been helpful if there were also recorded lectures along with the live lectures. I think this would have helped my understanding of the concepts discussed in class.

The asynchronous lectures were nice, as were ample office hours, but it would be great if the professor/TA could check edstem more -- there was opportunity for good discussion but things were often not addressed until it was too late (e.g., after problem set deadlines had passed). Also, recordings were often not posted in a timely manner, which could be frustrating. Finally, it was hard to get info about important aspects of the course (exam timing being a notable example), which was extra frustrating during COVID.

Lectures were recorded which was helpful for review. Discussion sections would have been nice, but I don't think they were even necessary. Professor Chang always made sure to leave time for questions at the end of lecture.
Online lectures were fine. I don't find virtual office hours very appealing for STEM classes, but that's my problem.
A success was the recorded lectures even though they were often posted late. A weakness was the lack of helpfulness from office hours and the late feedback time.
N/A
The recorded lectures were interesting but I would have appreciated some more interactive features, such as a discussion section.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this class to someone who just wanted to take one singular statistics class. If you plan on taking statistics beyond the introductory level, there is probably a better class out there. It also doesn't deal a ton with data manipulation, so if that's an interest of yours, there are other classes better suited for that.

I'd definitely recommend this course. This intensive intro to statistics allowed me to become a more valuable research assistant and data analyst. Now I'm equipped to perform any basic analysis in R and understand what lies behind p-values, R-squared, etc. The problem sets were also great, and many of the questions focused on the practical application of statistics.
Yes, great introduction to statistics and R. I feel like I learned a lot more than I would have in a non-intensive stats class.

I would definitely recommend this course to any major because data science is such an important tool. Compared to normal introduction statistics classes, this one includes a good amount of R, which is incredibly useful in any field. You will learn a lot of practical knowledge from this class.
This course may not be worth taking if another class like stats 230 is available
Yes. I thought I learned a lot in this course and knowing basic statistics and R is important

I would only recommend this course to a student who has previous experience in both statistics and coding. Although it is often described as an introductory course, having never worked with R or studied statistics in the past, I definitely faced difficulties throughout the course because of the pace and the material.
Yes -- overall a great way to get a solid statistical foundation

Absolutely. It was a challenge at times, but the challenging problems on psets were the most interesting ones. Plus, learning R is so useful and makes statistics that much more interesting and insightful.
Gotta put in a lot of elbow grease
I'd recommend you take stats 230!
Yes! It's interesting and difficult enough, but is not exhausting or impossible to grasp.
Professor Chang is a national treasure.

I would recommend this class. Prof. Chang was a clear instructor, and he introduced us to R at a very manageable pace. If you did not take statistics in high school, I would suggest looking at the first few chapters of the book before classes to get oriented.

I would if Professor Chang teaches it. He is super helpful and willing to explain concepts. The class is a super good Introductory Stats class for people who are interested but do not have any prior Stats experience.
Yes! Great intro to stats that gives you the tool to apply it and actually use it. Professor chang is great!
Yes, for studying the basics of statistics in a practical manner

NO NO NO NO NO NOOOOOOOOO! I must admit this class could be a very good class, the psets sometimes are good, however the professor is TRASH.  He literally could not care less about his students. FIRST of all he is a mess in lecture, he is using slides that he made a few year ago, and he gets them messed up all the time, also they are not even good. The lectures go everywhere, literally one second he is using his slides, the next he is coding, and the next he writes stuff on the board ( in our class one-note).  SECOND he is a horrendous writer, I have sometimes spent more time trying to understand what he wants in a pset than on the actual damn pset. Why don't I just email him? He does NOT TAKE EMAILS, he will send you this huge email that he copies and pastes, which basically says "just post it on Ed", this would be fine IF HE RESPONDED TO Ed, which HE DOES NOT. This guy has literally answered questions about psets 2 weeks after they were due, it is actually infuriating. The worse thing about all this, is that during exams he simply IGNORED our emails. THIRD: He is condescending to people who ask questions in class, I mean many times he has responded with an almost angry tone to people's questions, both in Office Hours  and in class. I liked the class, but it was also very frustrating and disliked professor Chang a lot. I would ONLY recommend this course if he is not teaching the class.
I would recommend this course to a student who knows they're interested in statistics and wants to be challenged. Otherwise I think a different class would be more interesting
I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn R and statistics

the lectures were also recorded.
This class consisted of an asynchronous recorded lecture and several office hour periods (4x per week).
Optional live virtual lecture.
Mostly went to the recorded lectures asynchronously!
Live virtual lecture recorded for asynchronous viewing.
Live virtual lecture
That's it!
Lectures were also recorded
n/a
None.
N/A
None other
